text: [music playing]

RASHA BASHA: I
fear for my family.

I worry especially
about my daughter,
who wears a headscarf.

I worry about my home,
my country, my US,
the greatest nation on Earth.

Honestly, it's not
just the election.

It's the election
and in turn, there's
so much hatred out there.

Hatred against Muslims is
just like, in my opinion,

it's a sign of
untreated disease.

SHADI MARTINI: My concern is
the fear, the level of tension,
getting higher.

People don't want
to communicate,

don't want to talk
to each other,

don't want to
understand each other,

and labeling each other
in a totally wrong way.

SHADI MARTINI: I worry
about this new ban that's

on immigration, especially
given that we're

banning people who are the
most vulnerable in the world
right now.

We shouldn't ban anyone,
but the people we're banning

are people who are escaping
war and threats to their life.

And if you look at
the Syrian refugees,

what they've been
through since 2011,

and the fact that we've
asked them not to come here

and that they're not welcome
really is really worse than--

ZUBAIR RUSHK: When
the elections started,

I tried to change my
name from Zubair to Zack

to not be prejudged by my
name, because election,
what the election did.

Today, if somebody asked
me, where are you from,
I will try to hide from.

I will say, I'm from Turkey, or
I'm from a different country,

to just not be prejudged by
people about where I came from.
